channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Myon Burrell Has Life Sentence Commuted by Minnesota
item.description: Mr. Burrell, who has maintained his innocence, was 16 when an 11-year-old was killed by a stray bullet. The case posed challenges for Senator Amy Klobuchar during her presidential campaign.
item.dc:creator: Will Wright
item.media:credit: John Minchillo/Associated Press
item.media:description: Myon Burrell, at the Minnesota Correctional Facility in Stillwater this February, had his life sentence for murder commuted by the state on Tuesday.

item.title: If Teachers Get the Vaccine Quickly, Can Students Get Back to School?
item.description: Teachers’ unions largely support plans to put educators near the front of the line, but given availability and logistics, that might not be enough to open more schools in the spring.
item.dc:creator: Eliza Shapiro and Shawn Hubler
item.media:credit: Lauren Justice for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mitch Arsenie, an environmental studies teacher at Carl Schurz High School in Chicago, teaching from home. Chicago is one of several cities where classrooms remain closed.

item.title: First Coronavirus Vaccines Bring Americans Hope in Small Doses
item.description: The vaccine campaign began on the same day that the nation surpassed 300,000 deaths, more than any other country.
item.dc:creator: Campbell Robertson, Amy Harmon and Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: Tim Gruber for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hundreds of medical workers received the United States’ first coronavirus vaccines on Monday, including Kenzie Frankl, a clinical care leader with Sanford Health in Fargo, N.D.

item.title: How Effective Is the Mask You’re Wearing? You May Know Soon
item.description: A C.D.C. division is working with an industry standards group to develop filtration standards — and products that meet them will be able to carry labels saying so.
item.dc:creator: Sheila Kaplan
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health
item.media:credit: Go Nakamura for The New York Times
item.media:description: New filtration standards being developed aim to help consumers understand just how effective the masks they buy really are.

item.title: Supreme Court to Rule on N.C.A.A. Limits on Paying College Athletes
item.description: An appeals court said restrictions on compensation tied to education violated federal antitrust laws.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Michael Woods/Associated Press
item.media:description: The N.C.A.A. has about 1,100 member schools, including Alabama and Arkansas, but most of them are far removed from the bright lights and big money of top-tier competitions.

item.title: States Plan to Accuse Google of Illegal Monopoly in Online Ads
item.description: The Texas attorney general said a coming lawsuit would focus on the advertisements that generate the vast majority of the company’s profits.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe
item.media:credit: John Taggart for The New York Times
item.media:description: The lawsuit against Google is the first by regulators in the United States to focus on the tools that connect buyers of advertising space with publishers who sell it.

item.title: New Scan Finds Prostate Cancer Cells Hiding in the Body
item.description: The test seems likely to improve the diagnosis and treatment of a disease that kills 33,000 American men each year.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times

item.title: Despite scaled-back plans, Biden inauguration offers perks to major donors.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth P. Vogel and Eric Lipton
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. spoke at a campaign drive-in event for Georgia’s Democratic Senate candidates in Atlanta on Tuesday.

item.title: National Endowment for the Humanities Announces New Grants
item.description: The final round of funding for the year totals $32.8 million and will support 213 projects across the country.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:credit: Evan Agostini/Invision, via Associated Press
item.media:description: This round of funding will enable the production of an interactive timeline of African-American music at Carnegie Hall.

item.title: U.S. Said to Be Near Charges for Another Suspect in 1988 Lockerbie Bombing
item.description: The attack on Pan Am flight 103 killed 270 people, including 189 Americans.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner and Adam Goldman
item.media:credit: Scott Heppell/Associated Press
item.media:description: A memorial for the 270 victims of Pan Am Flight 103 near Lockerbie, Scotland.

item.title: Cookie Monster Mural Puzzles Artist and Enrages Property Owner
item.description: A man claiming to be a property owner in Peoria, Ill., wanted a Soviet-style mural of Cookie Monster. The artist who did the job now says he was tricked (and paid) by an impostor.
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer
item.media:credit: Joshua Hawkins
item.media:description: The artist Joshua Hawkins said it took 10 people to complete the mural in Peoria, Ill., over Thanksgiving weekend.

item.title: How New York City Is Preparing for a Major Snowstorm
item.dc:creator: Corey Kilgannon
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: The New York City Department of Sanitation prepared its equipment on Tuesday for first big storm of the season.

item.title: Chicago Girl Raises $22,000 for Children’s Hospital With Friendship Bracelets
item.description: Hayley Orlinsky, 7, has sold some 9,000 bracelets to raise money for Covid-19 equipment at the hospital that cared for her as an infant.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:credit: Charles Rex Arbogast/Associated Press
item.media:description: Hayley has far surpassed her initial goal of raising $200 with the handicrafts.

item.title: When Will It Be Like 2019 Again?
item.description: Vaccines will soon be available for teachers — but what comes next is complicated.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Adam Pasick
item.media:credit: Mary Altaffer/Associated Press
item.media:description: Fourth-grade students sitting behind plexiglass at their desks in Rye, N.Y.

item.title: Billions Spent on U.S. Cyberdefenses Failed to Detect Giant Russian Hack
item.description: The broad Russian espionage attack on the U.S. government and private companies, underway since spring and detected only a few weeks ago, is among the greatest intelligence failures of modern times.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and Nicole Perlroth
item.media:credit: Jim Lo Scalzo/European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: The National Security Agency’s headquarters in Ft. Meade, Md. is home to a cyber war room guiding efforts that cost tens of billions of dollars.

item.title: In New York, outdoor dining confronts the approaching snowstorm.
item.description: But the storm will pose a significant test for how the city’s outdoor dining program can withstand severe winter weather.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.media:credit: James Estrin/The New York Times
item.media:description: Emmeline Zhao, a partner and the general manager of Silver Apricot in Manhattan, in front of the restaurant’s outdoor dining structure.

item.title: Snowstorm Impacts Travel in the Northeast
item.description: Transportation companies were modifying their operations and officials were warning motorists to take extra care on the roads.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor, Mihir Zaveri and Maria Jiminez Moya
item.media:credit: Luke Sharrett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amtrak Northeast Regional passenger trains during a previous snow storm in Trenton, N.J.

item.title: ‘This Was Coming Full Circle’
item.description: Wednesday: The intensive care nurse who was the first person in California to get a vaccine dose talks about the experience.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Jae C. Hong/Associated Press
item.media:description: Helen Cordova, an I.C.U. nurse, posed with her vaccination record card after receiving the Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine at Kaiser Permanente Los Angeles Medical Center on Monday.

item.title: Biden’s climate team begins to take shape.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport and Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Sarah Blesener for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gina McCarthy, the former Environmental Protection Agency administrator under President Barack Obama, is expected to be President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s pick as a senior adviser on climate change.

item.title: Trump Administration Says Vietnam and Switzerland Manipulated Currency
item.description: The decision to label the countries currency manipulators for the first time is likely to raise tensions with two trading partners.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Pool Photo by Sarah Silbiger
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin has formally accused Vietnam and Switzerland of manipulating their currencies to gain an advantage in global trade.

item.title: Wealthier, Whiter Areas Are More Likely to Get Help After Fires, Data Show
item.description: New research offers further signs that racial and economic inequality leave some Americans more exposed to the worsening effects of climate change.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:credit: Eric Thayer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Homes threatened by the Blue Ridge Fire in Irvine, Calif., in October.

item.title: Biden Rallies Democrats in Georgia
item.description: The president-elect chooses some familiar names for his cabinet: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: Comparing Virus Surges
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shops in Munich, Germany on Monday.

item.title: Experts Debate How to Revive the Economy After the Pandemic
item.description: A group of experts gathered to debate the priorities for economic policy with the end of the pandemic (seemingly) in sight.
item.dc:creator: Corinne Purtill
item.media:credit: Illustration by John Gall; Photographs by The New York Times

item.title: How Capitalism Is Coping in an Era of Populism
item.description: A group of experts gathered to debate the role of government and business, and what each can do to address rising anger over inequality.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced
item.media:credit: Illustration by John Gall; Photographs by The New York Times

item.title: What is a nor’easter, exactly?
item.description: The storms can produce dangerous conditions such as power outages, icy roads and fallen trees
item.dc:creator: Allyson Waller
item.media:credit: Brian Snyder/Reuters
item.media:description: In Somerville, Mass., this month.

item.title: From Voter Fraud to Vaccine Lies: Misinformation Peddlers Shift Gears
item.description: Election-related falsehoods have subsided, but misleading claims about the coronavirus vaccines are surging — often spread by the same people.
item.dc:creator: Davey Alba and Sheera Frenkel
item.media:credit: Jonathan Ernst/Reuters
item.media:description: Sidney Powell, who was a member of President Trump’s legal team, on Capitol Hill last month. She has started posting inaccurate claims about the coronavirus vaccines online.

item.title: Pandemic Leaves More Military Families Seeking Food Assistance
item.description: Veterans are in a similar situation, hunger advocates and service organizations have found.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Steinhauer
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Travis Dove for The New York Times
item.media:description: April Reibestein, a volunteer at the Armed Services Y.M.C.A. at Fort Bragg, N.C., preparing orders for contactless pickup at a food bank serving military families on the base.

item.title: Nikki Giovanni, Finding the Song in the Darkest Days
item.description: Part of the Black Arts Movement in the 1960s, part of a Biden campaign ad in 2020, she has never stopped writing.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth A. Harris
item.media:credit: Shaban Athuman for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I thought 50 years ago that I could make a big difference in the world,” Nikki Giovanni said. “What I know now is that I will not allow the world to make a big difference in me.”

item.title: ‘Like a Hand Grasping’: Trump Appointees Describe the Crushing of the C.D.C.
item.description: Kyle McGowan, a former chief of staff at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, and his deputy, Amanda Campbell, go public on the Trump administration’s manipulation of the agency.
item.dc:creator: Noah Weiland
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Audra Melton for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Every time that the science clashed with the messaging, messaging won,” said Kyle McGowan, a former chief of staff of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

item.title: Senator Jon Tester on Democrats and Rural Voters: ‘Our Message Is Really, Really Flawed’
item.description: Mr. Tester, a Montana farmer, detailed in an interview how Democrats had failed to connect with many voters: “You cannot have Chuck Schumer talking rural issues to rural people.”
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Martin
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Jon Tester said Democrats “have to do a better job developing a message so that rural Americans can say, ‘Yeah, those guys, they think like I do.’”

item.title: Santa Tests Positive for Coronavirus After Photo Session With 50 Children
item.description: A husband and wife who dressed up as Santa and Mrs. Claus for an annual Christmas parade and tree-lighting ceremony in Georgia learned three days after the festivities that they had the coronavirus, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: WTOC-TV
item.media:description: The pavilion in Ludowici, Ga., where two people portraying Santa and Mrs. Claus held a photo session with children as part of the holiday festivities. The couple later tested positive for the coronavirus.

item.title: Biden’s Climate Team Begins to Take Shape
item.description: The president-elect is expected to pick Gina McCarthy, a former E.P.A. chief, as White House climate coordinator. Jennifer Granholm, a former Michigan governor, is said to be his choice for the Energy Department.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport and Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Sarah Blesener for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gina McCarthy led the Environmental Protection Agency from 2013 to 2017 and helped design Obama-era climate regulations.

item.title: Biden Taps Pete Buttigieg for Transportation Secretary
item.description: Mr. Buttigieg would bring a younger voice to the cabinet and add to its diversity as its first openly gay member.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein and Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: Travis Dove for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pete Buttigieg, the former mayor of South Bend, Ind., in February in South Carolina during his primary presidential campaign.

item.title: MacKenzie Scott Announces $4.2 Billion More in Charitable Giving
item.description: “She’s disrupting the norms around billionaire philanthropy by moving quickly,” an expert on charities said.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Kulish
item.media:credit: Jorg Carstensen/DPA, via Agence France-Presse
item.media:description: MacKenzie Scott has given nearly $4.2 billion to 384 organizations in just the last four months, she said on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. and Pfizer Are Negotiating Deal for More Vaccine Doses Next Year
item.description: The Trump administration is discussing helping the drug maker get the raw materials it would need to produce tens of millions of extra doses of its Covid-19 vaccine in the spring.
item.dc:creator: Sharon LaFraniere, Katie Thomas and Noah Weiland
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: A batch of the Pfizer vaccine arriving at NewYork-Presbyterian/Columbia University Irving Medical Center in Manhattan.

item.title: Biden Campaigns in Georgia, Presses for the Senate Majority He Will Need
item.description: The president-elect urged voters at a rally in Atlanta to defeat both the state’s incumbent Republican senators and elect Jon Ossoff and Raphael Warnock, which would give Democrats Senate control.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas and Michael D. Shear
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. campaigning with the Rev. Raphael G. Warnock, the Democratic candidate for one of Georgia’s Senate seats, in Atlanta on Tuesday.

item.title: Leaders in Congress Meet in Search of Stimulus and Spending Deals
item.description: The top four congressional leaders had their first in-person spending discussions in months, but were still short of a deal on a pandemic stimulus measure or a broader spending plan.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Mitch McConnell on his way to meet with Speaker Nancy Pelosi, Senator Chuck Schumer and Representative Kevin McCarthy on Tuesday at the Capitol.

item.title: Biden to Name Gina McCarthy, Former E.P.A. Chief, as White House Climate Coordinator
item.description: Ms. McCarthy will serve as a senior adviser to President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr., coordinating climate change policy throughout the government.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Sarah Blesener for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gina McCarthy led the Environmental Protection Agency from 2013 to 2017 and helped design Obama-era climate regulations.

item.title: Dominion’s C.E.O. defends his firm’s voting machines to Michigan lawmakers, denouncing a ‘reckless disinformation campaign.’
item.dc:creator: Kathleen Gray
item.media:credit: John Bazemore/Associated Press
item.media:description: A demonstration in Atlanta of a Dominion Voting Systems machine in 2019.

item.title: Drug Makers Are Pulling Back From a Program to Help the Needy
item.description: Some pharmaceutical companies are scaling back their participation in a federally mandated drug discount program. State attorneys general are demanding that the administration take action.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: A group of state attorneys general has called on the health secretary, Alex M. Azar II, to confront drug makers who are no longer meeting the requirements of a federal program to help hospitals and clinics serving the poor.

item.title: D.C. Passes Bill to Give Young Offenders Chance at Reduced Sentences
item.description: Fueled by a debate over when the justice system should consider young people adults, the legislation would apply to those under 25 when they committed a crime who have served at least 15 years.
item.dc:creator: Hailey Fuchs
item.media:credit: Brandon Bell/Getty Images
item.media:description: Activists had mounted a clemency campaign to spare the life of Brandon Bernard, who was executed by the Justice Department on Thursday for murders he helped commit when he was 18.

item.title: Defying Trump, McConnell Seeks to Squelch Bid to Overturn the Election
item.description: Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, congratulated President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. and pleaded with Republicans privately not to join an effort by House members to throw out the results.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: “The Electoral College has spoken. So today, I want to congratulate President-elect Joe Biden,” Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, said on Tuesday.

item.title: Biden to Pick Jennifer Granholm, Former Michigan Governor, for Energy Secretary
item.description: Ms. Granholm is widely credited with steering her state through a recession and working with the Obama administration on a bailout of the automobile industry.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Steve Jennings/Getty Images For Techcrunch
item.media:description: If confirmed, Ms. Granholm, 61, would oversee the United States nuclear weapons complex and a wide range of energy research initiatives.

item.title: Is the Legal System an Effective Solution to Domestic Violence?
item.description: FKA Twigs has highlighted a problem that 1 in 3 American women face. But it is still rare for aggressors to face charges, convictions or financial penalties.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta
item.media:credit: Chiara Zarmati

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: The F.D.A. confirmed that Moderna’s vaccine was highly effective in preventing Covid-19.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: California Travel Restrictions Ban Short-Term Rentals. Why Can't Travelers Get Refunds?
item.description: The state’s latest travel restrictions make most hotel or short term lodging illegal. But Airbnb and Vrbo, the biggest home-sharing companies, are sticking to no-refund policies.
item.dc:creator: Julie Weed
item.media:credit: Beth Coller for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Highland Park neighborhood in Los Angeles, where short-term rentals are currently restricted to only essential workers.
